case_name: Appellants v. State of Madhya Pradesh

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 645/1961 is before the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 645/1961. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated April 20, 1957,

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated April 20, 1957 of Madhya Pradesh High Court in First Appeal No. 181/52.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated April 20, 1957, of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in First Appeal No. 181/52. Hardayal Hardy, S. AT. Andley and Rameshwar Nath, for the appellant.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate on April 16, 1958 under Art. 133 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal on a certificate granted by the High Court of Madhya Pradesh at Jabalpur on April 16, 1958, under Art. 133 of the Constitution, is directed against the judgment and decree of that Court in First Appeal No. 181 of 1962,

facts.text: Additional District Judge, Chindwara decided Civil Suit No. 3-A of 1951 on September 25, 1952 decreeing plaintiffs claim for Rs. 40865 and interest.

anchor.surface_text: reversing those of the Additional District judge, Chindwara, in Civil Suit No. 3-A of 1951, decided on September 25, 1952, by which the trial Court had decreed the plaintiffs claim for Rs. 408651-and interest.

facts.text: Haji Syed Zahiruddin of Bhopal held mining lease Ex. P-2 dated May 29, 1923 in respect of 189-76 acres of land in Chindwara for extracting companyl.

anchor.surface_text: It is necessary to state the following facts in order to bring out the points in companytroversy between the parties. One Haji Syed Zahiruddin of Bhopal held a mining lease-Ex. P-2-dated May 29, 1923 in respect of 189-76 acres of land in the district of Chindwara, for extracting companyl.

facts.text: Appellants took assignment of the lease by Ex. P1 dated September 4, 1940.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants took an assignment of that lease by Ex. PI dated September 4, 1940. There were companyl bearing areas adjacent to the area companyered by the lease aforesaid.

facts.text: Appellants entered into agreement with Government on January 11, 1946 Ex.P3 raising royalty from Rs. 5/- to Rs. 10/- per ton.

anchor.surface_text: After protracted companyrespondence and negotiations, the Government agreed to grant the necessary sanction to the transfer of those adjacent lands to the appellants subject to the companydition that they took a companysolidated lease in respect of the whole additional area at an enhanced rate of royalty. The appellants entered into an agreement with the Government on January 11, 1946  Ex.P3  by which the rate of royalty payable to Government was raised from Rs. 5/-to Rs. 10/-per ton.

facts.text: Appellants worked the mines with permission of Government from October 27, 1947 to June 30, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Though numberformal lease deed was executed, the appellants worked the mines with the permission of the Government during the period October 27, 1947 to June 30, 1949.

facts.text: Appellants paid Rs. 40865/- including interest to Government by way of royalty for coal extracted.

anchor.surface_text: In respect of the companyl thus extracted, the appellants paid to the Government the sum of Rs. 40865/-, including interest, by way of royalty.

facts.text: Plaintiffs paid the sum of Rs. 40865/- under protest in February-March, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs paid the aforesaid sum under protest in February-March, 1960.

facts.text: Plaintiffs commenced suit in February 1951 against State of Madhya Pradesh for declaration, injunction and refund of Rs. 40865 plus interest.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs companymenced the present action in February 1951, for a declaration that they were number bound by the terms of the agreement dated January 11, 1949, aforesaid,. and that, therefore, they were number liable to pay to Government any sum in excess of that fixed by the lease of 1923, and. by the lease of January 21, 1944, in respect of lands transferred to them. They also. claimed an injunction against the defendant, the State of Madhya Pradesh, which was the sole defendant,, number respondent. There wag also a prayer for refund of the said amount of Rs. 40865/- plus interest amounting to Rs. 1985/

facts.text: Plaintiffs contended agreement void as contravention of r. 50 of Mining Rules of 1913 and s. 4 of Mines and Minerals Regulation and Development Act XIII of 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The companytentions raised on behalf of the plaintiffs in support of their claim were that the agreement aforesaid was void as it was in companytravention of r. 50 of the Mining Rules of 1913, as also that the same was in companytravention of s. 4 of the Mines and Minerals  Regulation and Development  Act  XIII of 1948 .

facts.text: Plaintiffs contended agreement entered under influence of misrepresentation by Government about new policy on mining leases.

anchor.surface_text: It was also companytended that a representation was made by the Government in the companyrespondence that passed between the parties that Government was going to adopt a new policy in respect of mining leases, including grant of leases at enhanced royalty. The agreement, the plaintiffs further asserted, had been entered into under the influence of that misrepresentation and was, therefore, number enforceable against them.

facts.text: Government contested suit stating Mineral Rules of 1913 had no binding effect after Constitution Act of 1935, mere departmental instructions.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was companytested by the Government on the ground that the Mineral Rules of 1913 had numberbinding effect after the Constitution Act of 1935, so far as the Provinces were companycerned those Rules were mere departmental instructions for the guidance of subordinate officers of the Government and that the Government was free to make its own bargain in respect of fresh leases.

facts.text: Government denied misrepresentation and stated intended new rules did not materialise.

anchor.surface_text: The Government also denied that there was any misrepresentation made by Government to the plaintiffs, though it was true that Government had intended to promulgate fresh rules which envisage revised scales of royalty, but which ultimately did number materialise.

facts.text: Trial court decreed suit on September 25, 1952 with costs, declaration and refund Rs. 40865 + Rs. 992/8/- interest.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Additional District judge, Chindwara, by his judgment and decree date September 25, 1952, decreed the suit with companyts holding that the plaintiffs were entitled to the declaration ,,ought by them, as also to the companysequen- tial relief of refund of the amount paid by them tinder protest, as aforesaid, namely, the sum of Rs. 40865/- together with the sum of Rs. 992/8/- on account of interest at 3 per annum up to the date of the suit, as also interest pendente lite tip to the date of realisation at the same rate of 3.

facts.text: High Court reversed trial court decree and dismissed suit with costs.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal by the defendant, the state of Madhya Pradesh, the High Court reversed the judgment and decree passed by the trial Court and passed a deeree dismissing the suit with companyts throughout.

facts.text: High Court held Government not bound by Rules of 1913 which had no statutory force, Rules of 1949 no retrospective operation, no misrepresentation.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the Government was number bound by the Rules of 1913, which had numberstatutory force, and that the Rules of 1949 made under the Act of 1948 aforesaid did number apply to the transaction in question, because they had numberretrospective operation. The High Court also held that there was numbermisrepresentation by the Government and that the plaintiffs were anxious to enter into the agreement in order to start their mining operations to take advantage of the High market in respect of companyl, and that they entered into the agreement with their eyes open and without any vitiating influence.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on November 19, 1962 by SINHA, C. J.

anchor.surface_text: Sen and 1. N. Shroff, for the respondent. 1962. November 19. The judgment of the Court was delivered by SINHA, C. J.-This appeal on a certificate granted by the High Court of Madhya Pradesh at Jabalpur on April 16, 1958, under Art. 133 of the Constitution,

facts.text: Supreme Court held Rules of 1913 not binding on Government itself, Governor could make exception as lessor in Ex. P3.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, this companytention is well- founded. Rule 1, which runs as follows, itself makes it clear that the Government companycerned may make an exception to the general rule laid down in the rule No license to prospect for minerals or lease of. mines and minerals can be granted by any Local Government otherwise than in accordance with these rules, except with the previous sanction of the Secretary of State for India in Council, or with that of the Governor-General in Council under any general or special authority which he may have received in this behalf from the Secretary of State in Council.

facts.text: Mines and Minerals Regulation and Development Act 1948 came into force on September 8, 1948; Mineral Concession Rules 1949 effective October 25, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The Act came into force on September 8, 1948, and the Rules, called the Mineral Concession Rules, 1949, were promulgated under s. 5 of the Act. But these Rules came into effect on October 25, 1949.

facts.text: Supreme Court held no misrepresentation vitiating agreement; appellants entered with eyes open.

anchor.surface_text: The only other ground on which the enforceability of the terms of the agreement has been questioned is that there was a misrepresentation by Government to the effect that it was going to enhance the rate of royalty all round, and that it was under the influence of that belief that the appellants entered into the agreement in question. ... As pointed out by the High Court, the appellants were in a hurry to take the additional area and work the companyl mines on terms which were mutually agreed between the parties.

This appeal on a certificate granted by the High Court of Madhya Pradesh at Jabalpur on April 16, 1958, under Art. 133 of the Constitution, is directed against the judgment and decree of that Court in First Appeal No. 181 of 1962,

Rule 1, which runs as follows, itself makes it clear that the Government concerned may make an exception to the general rule laid down in the rule No license to prospect for minerals or lease of. mines and minerals can be granted by any Local Government otherwise than in accordance with these rules, except with the previous sanction of the Secretary of State for India in Council, or with that of the Governor-General in Council under any general or special authority which he may have received in this behalf from the Secretary of State in Council.

holdings.text: The Rules of 1913 were not binding on the Government itself as they were departmental instructions and Rule 1 expressly permitted exceptions by higher authorities, substituted post-1935 by the Governor who was the lessor and presumed to have authorized the enhanced royalty terms.

anchor.surface_text: In this Court it was strenuously argued on behalf of the appellants that the Rules of 1913 were in terms imperative and had statutory force which bound the State Government, and that any lease or agreement entered into between the parties in violation of the terms of these Rules would be wholly void.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 1 allows Local Government to grant licenses/leases otherwise than per rules with sanction of Secretary of State or Governor-General; post-1935 Governor empowered and as lessor in Ex.P3 presumed acted in State interest.

holdings.text: Even assuming the Rules of 1913 had statutory force, the Governor as grantor/lessor must be presumed to have decided that the revised terms were in the interest of the State, making them binding.

anchor.surface_text: In this case, it is clear from Ex. P. 3--the agreement dated January 11, 1946 that the Governor was in the position of the lessor. Hence, even if we assume that the Rules had statutory force and applied, to the instant case, the Governor having been the grantor of the lease it must be presumed that he decided that the revised terms were in the interest of the State, and, therefore, the revised terms of the lease were binding on the parties.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Governor substituted for prior authorities under Govt of India Act 1935; as lessor in agreement, authorization presumed.

holdings.text: The agreement is not void as contravening s.4 of the 1948 Act or 1949 Rules as they have no retrospective effect and apply only to leases granted after October 25, 1949; agreement predates and mining occurred before.

anchor.surface_text: In this connection it is necessary to consider the alternative ground of attack based on the provisions of the Act of 1948 and the Rules made thereunder. The Act came into force on September 8, 1948, and the Rules, called the Mineral Concession Rules, 1949, were promulgated under s. 5 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Act effective Sep 8 1948, Rules Oct 25 1949; s.4 prohibits grants after commencement except per rules; negotiations finalized Jan 1946, operations 1947-49 before rules.

holdings.text: There was no misrepresentation, undue influence, coercion or mutual mistake vitiating the agreement; appellants entered knowingly with eyes open after negotiations, anxious to mine.

anchor.surface_text: The only other ground on which the enforceability of the terms of the agreement has been questioned is that there was a misrepresentation by Government to the effect that it was going to enhance the rate of royalty all round, and that it was under the influence of that belief that the appellants entered into the agreement in question.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No allegation of undue influence/coercion/mutual mistake; draft rules not finalized does not vitiate; parties mutually agreed terms despite onerous nature.

holdings.text: The agreement terms do not amount to deprivation of property without authority of law under Art. 31(1); payment was under enforceable contract, not State deprivation.

anchor.surface_text: There was a faint attempt made on behalf of the appellants to put their objections on a constitutional basis. It was contended that the terms imposed upon the appellants by the State would amount to deprivation of property without the authority of law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No deprivation by State; voluntary payment under valid contract; even assuming Constitution applied (obiter).

justification_sets.label: Section 4, Mines and Minerals (Regulation and Development) Act, 1948 support

anchor.surface_text: Under the agreement which we hold to be enforceable, the defendant may have struck a hard bargain but that cannot be brought under the prohibition of Art. 31 (1) of the Constitution, even assuming that the Constitution applied to the transaction in question.

outcome.relief_summary: Agreement held enforceable; declaration that agreement void denied; refund of Rs. 40865/- and interest denied

anchor.surface_text: In this Court it was strenuously argued on behalf of the appellants that the Rules of 1913 were in terms imperative and had statutory force which bound the State Government, and that any lease or agreement entered into between the parties in violation of the terms of these Rules would be wholly void.

anchor.surface_text: Under the agreement which we hold to be enforceable, the defendant may have struck a hard bargain but that cannot be brought under the prohibition of Art. 31 (1) of the Constitution, even assuming that the Constitution applied to the transaction in question.

edges.explanation: Holding h2 argues that even assuming statutory force, the Governor must be presumed to have decided revised terms in State interest, addressing permission to grant otherwise under Rule 1

anchor.surface_text: In this case, it is clear from Ex. P. 3--the agreement dated January 11, 1946 that the Governor was in the position of the lessor. Hence, even if we assume that the Rules had statutory force and applied, to the instant case, the Governor having been the grantor of the lease it must be presumed that he decided that the revised terms were in the interest of the State, and, therefore, the revised terms of the lease were binding on the parties.

Under the agreement which we hold to be enforceable, the defendant may have struck a hard bargain but that cannot be brought under the prohibition of Art. 31 (1) of the Constitution, even assuming that the Constitution applied to the transaction in question.

anchor.surface_text: In this connection it is necessary to consider the alternative ground of attack based on the provisions of the Act of 1948 and the Rules made thereunder. The Act came into force on September 8, 1948, and the Rules, called the Mineral Concession Rules, 1949, were promulgated under s. 5 of the Act.

Under the agreement which we hold to be enforceable, the defendant may have struck a hard bargain but that cannot be brought under the prohibition of Art. 31 (1) of the Constitution, even assuming that the Constitution applied to the transaction in question.

edges.explanation: Holding of no misrepresentation supports the concept
Holding resolves the issue by denying misrepresentation

anchor.surface_text: The only other ground on which the enforceability of the terms of the agreement has been questioned is that there was a misrepresentation by Government to the effect that it was going to enhance the rate of royalty all round, and that it was under the influence of that belief that the appellants entered into the agreement in question.

Under the agreement which we hold to be enforceable, the defendant may have struck a hard bargain but that cannot be brought under the prohibition of Art. 31 (1) of the Constitution, even assuming that the Constitution applied to the transaction in question.

There was a faint attempt made on behalf of the appellants to put their objections on a constitutional basis. It was contended that the terms imposed upon the appellants by the State would amount to deprivation of property without the authority of law.
